question_text: Analyze the thermodynamic stability differences between microemulsions and conventional emulsions (nanoemulsions/macroemulsions) in the context of emulsion fuel combustion systems, and explain how these stability characteristics impact microexplosion phenomena and NOx/PM emissions reduction in diesel engines.
standard_answer: The fundamental thermodynamic distinction lies in microemulsions being thermodynamically stable systems while conventional emulsions are kinetically stabilized. Microemulsions form spontaneously due to their thermodynamically favored state, as evidenced by the paper's definition: 'Microemulsions are thermodynamically stable and can form spontaneously. Unlike regular emulsions, microemulsions are thermodynamically stable and can form spontaneously.' This spontaneous formation occurs because the system achieves a lower Gibbs free energy state through interfacial tension reduction by surfactants. In contrast, conventional emulsions require external energy input and exist in metastable states: 'Nanoemulsions and macroemulsions are thermodynamically unstable since the separated phases have a lower Gibbs free energy than the emulsion. On the other hand, kinetically stable emulsions are possible, but they require external energy to mix water, oil and surfactants.' This thermodynamic stability difference directly impacts combustion performance. Microemulsions provide ultra-long storage stability, ensuring consistent fuel properties over time, while conventional emulsions may phase separate, affecting fuel consistency. The stability characteristics influence microexplosion behavior - stable water droplet dispersion in microemulsions ensures predictable secondary atomization, enhancing air-fuel mixing and promoting more uniform combustion. This improved mixing, combined with water's cooling effect, simultaneously reduces NOx formation through lower peak temperatures and PM emissions through better fuel distribution and hydroxyl radical generation from water dissociation.
